testCase.expectations:
- titles should look like these: "Programação","Ciência da Computação","Desenvolvimento Web","Engenharia de Software"
      - all titles and descriptions in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None

Title capitalization errors against the provided expectations: "Ciência Da Computação" should be "Ciência da Computação" and "Engenharia De Software" should be "Engenharia de Software"; minor phrasing issue in some descriptions (e.g., "Desenvolva habilidades em criar" sounds slightly unnatural in Brazilian Portuguese, better "para criar"); some description redundancy but acceptable.

Fix Portuguese title capitalization for prepositions/articles (da, de); slightly vary and polish descriptions for naturalness and specificity (e.g., clarify outcomes or contexts); optionally add a few more relevant single-topic suggestions tailored to coding goals, such as "Lógica de Programação", "Algoritmos", "Estruturas de Dados", "Desenvolvimento Front-End", "Desenvolvimento Back-End", or "Banco de Dados"—ensuring no joined topics in a single title.

testCase.expectations:
- should include "Derecho Penal"
      - may include broader topics like "Derecho" or "Criminología"
      - all titles and descriptions in Spain Spanish

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None. The output follows the core rules: includes the exact topic "Derecho Penal", uses Spanish, titles have no levels or joiners, and each description is exactly one sentence.

Slight mismatch with Spain Spanish: terms like "regulaciones" and the title "Derecho Criminal" are less common in Spain (more typical would be "normativas/reglamentos" and sticking to "Derecho Penal"). Descriptions are generic and could better highlight usefulness. Title variety could be broader as two titles are near-synonyms.

Add broader and related suggestions for variety (e.g., "Derecho", "Criminología", "Derecho Procesal Penal", "Política Criminal", "Victimología"). Refine descriptions to clearly state learner value and use Spain Spanish lexicon (e.g., "normativa", "jurisprudencia", "procesal"). Consider replacing "Derecho Criminal" with a more Spain-standard alternative.

userInput.prompt: i want an intro to chemistry

testCase.expectations:
- should include "Chemistry" (without "Intro" or "Introduction")
      - do NOT include "Intro to Chemistry"
      - may include broader or similar topics but it's not required
      - all titles and descriptions in US English

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None. The suggestions adhere to language, title formatting, topic relevance, and sentence-length rules; no forbidden title elements like "Intro" or level markers appear.

One description uses the word "basic" ("basic concepts"), which lightly conflicts with the expectation to avoid level/joiner words; descriptions are somewhat generic and repetitive (all start with "This course...") and do not strongly emphasize learner benefits.

Rephrase descriptions to highlight learner outcomes/benefits and avoid level terms (e.g., replace "basic concepts" with "core concepts"); vary phrasing beyond "This course..."; optionally add closely related suggestions like Analytical Chemistry or Biochemistry to broaden options.

userInput.prompt: i want to pass the JLPT N2

testCase.expectations:
- should include "JLPT" without the "N2" level suffix
      - should include "Japanese"
      - all titles and descriptions in US English
      - no extra titles like "Japanese Language Proficiency Test", "JLPT N2 Preparation", etc
      - should NOT include any other suggestions

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None

The description for the title "Japanese" is incorrect, calling it a proficiency test instead of describing the language learning course and why it is useful; this reduces clarity and does not meet the guidance that descriptions highlight relevance.

Revise the "Japanese" description to reflect learning benefits (e.g., communication, study, work); make the "JLPT" description more learner-oriented (e.g., usefulness for certification or goals) while keeping one sentence and avoiding level mentions.

testCase.expectations:
- should ONLY include "IELTS" and "Inglês", strip "Academic" suffix
      - all titles and descriptions in Brazilian Portuguese
      - no extra titles like "Testes de Proficiência em Inglês", "Preparatório para o IELTS", etc
      - should NOT include any other suggestions

      
  - The main focus is the `title` field, no need to pay much attention to the `description` field
  - No level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - No words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are always in Title Case

steps.conclusion: None. The response follows the language-exam edge case: exactly two suggestions, correct titles (“IELTS” and “Inglês”), titles in Title Case, and content in Brazilian Portuguese.

Minor issue: the first description explicitly references the Academic variant (“exame acadêmico”), which could be seen as conflicting with the instruction to strip the Academic suffix (even though this restriction applies primarily to titles). Slightly awkward phrasing (“exame acadêmico de inglês IELTS”).

Rephrase the first description to avoid mentioning the Academic variant and improve naturalness, e.g., “Prepare-se para o IELTS com foco no formato e conteúdo da prova.” Optionally tighten the second description for clarity and outcome orientation.
